newsitem.title: UKRAINE: EU wants more progress before giving Ukraine loans.
newsitem.headline: EU wants more progress before giving Ukraine loans.

text.p: Ukraine will have to take more steps to improve its economy if it hopes to receive two European Union credits totalling 350 million ECU ($437 million) for this year and 1997, an EU director said on Friday.

Ukraine is awaiting delivery of a 100 million ECU ($125 million) tranche from a 200 million ECU ($250 million) loan agreed earlier this year, and has requested a 250 million ECU ($312 million) loan for 1997, Joly Dixon, a European Commission economic director, said.
"There are measures to be taken before the second tranche can be disbursed," Dixon said at a news conference at the end of a two-day visit to Kiev.

He said outstanding points to be settled for the tranche included implementation of simpler import certification procedures and removal of discriminatory excise laws, as well as better public procurement practices.

The EU also wanted to see increased foreign direct investment -- Ukraine has only attracted $1.2 billion in investment since independence in 1991 -- and creation of a more competitive privatisation process.
Dixon said he expected the issues to be resolved soon and that the money could be delivered "very early next year."
The EU has given Ukraine $4 billion in grants and balance of payments loans since it won independence in 1991, including a $675 million technical aid deal signed in September.

The EU director said Ukraine's receipt of the 1997 loan depended on sustained economic progress, approval from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a $2.5 to $3 billion Extended Fund Facility (EFF), and passage of the 1997 budget.

"The economic programme which forms the basis of government reforms, and the basis of agreement of negotiations with the IMF for the Extended Fund Facility, depends on the adoption of a very radical budget and very far-reaching reforms," he said.

The budget draft, agreed with the IMF, forecasts a budget deficit at 5.5 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) -- four percent by Western calculations -- and foresees inflation at 25 percent, down from an expected 40 percent this year.
But the left-dominated parliament is expected to give the budget a rough ride and may demand significant changes.
By law it is to be approved by January 1 but officials have predicted it may be delayed by as much as several months.

An IMF board is expected to decide this month or next whether Ukraine, which eventually hopes to become a member of the European Union, will receive the EFF, which would succeed the $867 million stand-by programme agreed in May.
